musicalLanguage.description: Billy Strayhorn wrote this tune on the subway, and it became the theme song of the Duke Ellington Orchestra. The melody is bright and optimistic, built on a simple ascending figure over basic jazz changes. The #4 note (F#) over C major gives it that distinctive, sparkling lift.
musicalLanguage.structure: AABA — 32 bars. This excerpt: first A section (8 bars)
keyMoments: Bar 1-2: The ascending melody with the characteristic F#4 — the lydian sparkle
Bar 3-4: Melody continues climbing toward G5 — riding the A train uptown
Bar 7-8: Phrase resolves to C with a classic swing ending figure
teachingGoals: Swing feel at a comfortable medium tempo
The #4 (F#) over a major chord — lydian color in practice
Simple left-hand stride: bass note on 1-3, chord on 2-4
styleTips: Bright and happy — this tune smiles. Play with energy.
Swing the eighths but keep it light — medium swing, not heavy
The F# is not a mistake — lean into it, that is the sound

measures.teachingNote: CMaj7 — the melody climbs up with F# as the surprise note. This is the 'A Train' sound.
CMaj7 continues. G4 resolves the chromatic climb. Let it breathe.
D7 — same melody, but the left hand shifts to D7. The F# now fits both melody and chord!
D7 continues. Melody peaks at A4 and descends to G4.
Dm7 — the ii chord. Melody descends from E5. Left hand supports gently.
G7 — the V chord. Melody continues its descent. Resolution is coming.
CMaj7 — arrival! Melody leaps up to C5 in a classic swing gesture.
CMaj7 — rest on the tonic. Clean ending. Ready to loop back to bar 1.
